prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, sir. I heard that you were referred to our department with a swollen cheek and eyelid. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, doc. I have a painless swelling on my right cheek and eyelid. It's been growing gradually for at least a month now.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Have you received any treatment for it?
Patient: Yes, I was given antibiotics but there was no improvement.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. Do you have any other symptoms like rhinorrhea?
Patient: Yes, I do have clear rhinorrhea.
Doctor: Alright. Do you have a history of close contact with sheep and dogs?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: Okay. Let's do a physical examination then. Can you tell me if there's any tenderness in the affected area?
Patient: No, there's no tenderness.
Doctor: Alright. I see a well-shaped, firm, and fluctuant swelling with subcutaneous penetration. Is there any evidence of inflammation?
Patient: No, there's no inflammation.
Doctor: Alright. Anterior rhinoscopy revealed lateral bulging of the right nasal wall. Your general condition is otherwise normal. 
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Great. We also did a Computed tomography imaging of the face. It showed a loculated soft tissue density in the right maxillary sinus with erosion of the lateral and medial walls, as well as the floor of the orbit. The soft tissue density involved the orbit and compressed the globe. The appearance of the suspected mass by CT was suggestive of a cystic mass.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: We tried to perform a fine-needle aspiration but it failed to provide sufficient material for fluid analysis. Given the compression of the orbit, we decided to resect the mass.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We adopted a Caldwell-Luc approach for the excision of the cystic mass. The mass in the maxillary sinus was yellow-white in color and elastic in nature, suggesting parasitic disease. We carefully removed the cystic mass and irrigated the sinus with hypertonic saline a total of three times. The macroscopic appearance of the extracted mass suggested a hydatid cyst. The cyst was enucleated easily, and multiple daughter cysts were found inside the capsule.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: The histopathologic examination revealed a hydatid cyst consistent with E. granulosus. A serologic test of the hydatid cyst revealed a positive 1/264 result, which further confirmed the presence of hydatid disease.
Patient: So, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means that you have hydatid disease. We also did an abdominal ultrasound and CT scan of the abdomen and thorax, and it ruled out any visceral or pulmonary involvement in the hydatid disease. This confirmed the diagnosis of a primary hydatid cyst of the right maxillary sinus.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: You're in a healthy condition now after the surgery. But we need to monitor your condition and do regular check-ups to ensure that the disease doesn't spread to other parts of your body.
Patient: Alright, doc. I'll follow your instructions.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, sir. I am Dr. Smith. How can I help you today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I developed a headache and some other symptoms recently.
Doctor: Okay, can you tell me more about your symptoms? When did they start?
Patient: It started suddenly about two weeks ago. I had a headache on the left side of my head, dizziness, trouble swallowing, and numbness on my right side.
Doctor: I see. And did you go to the hospital at that time?
Patient: Yes, I was transported to another hospital. They did a head MRI and found a problem in my brain.
Doctor: Okay, I see. And what did the MRI show?
Patient: They said I had a left lateral medullary infarction due to the left vertebral artery dissection.
Doctor: I see. And what kind of treatment did you receive at that hospital?
Patient: They didn't give me any antiplatelet or anticoagulant agents. They just gave me a free radical scavenger and some mild volume expansion.
Doctor: I see. And what was your blood pressure like during that time?
Patient: It was around 130/80 mmHg. So, they didn't give me any antihypertensive agents.
Doctor: Okay. And did your symptoms get worse after that?
Patient: No, I had an uneventful course and my symptoms didn't get worse.
Doctor: That's good to hear. And why did you come to our hospital?
Patient: My family and I wanted to come here, so we transferred here four days after the onset.
Doctor: I see. And did we perform another head MRI here?
Patient: Yes, you did. And the findings were the same as the other hospital.
Doctor: I see. And were there any abnormal findings in your right vertebral artery?
Patient: No, there weren't any.
Doctor: Okay. And what happened after that?
Patient: Nine days after the onset, I suddenly lost consciousness and was found lying on the side of my bed.
Doctor: I see. And did we perform a head CT scan at that time?
Patient: Yes, you did. And it showed that I had a subarachnoid hemorrhage, mainly in the posterior cranial fossa.
Doctor: I see. And did we perform a 3D CT angiography?
Patient: Yes, you did. And it showed that I had a dissecting aneurysm with active extravasation of contrast agent in my right vertebral artery.
Doctor: I see. And did we perform an emergency internal coil trapping for the aneurysm?
Patient: Yes, you did. Under general anesthesia.
Doctor: I see. And did we perform any endovascular treatment for the stenotic portion of your left vertebral artery?
Patient: No, you didn't. The basilar artery was visualized in antegrade with no delay of blood flow, so you didn't perform any endovascular treatment.
Doctor: I see. And did you have any ischemic symptoms due to vasospasm after the SAH?
Patient: No, I didn't. My condition improved gradually, and I was discharged with a modified Rankin Scale score of 1.
Doctor: That's great to hear. And do you have any questions for me?
Patient: No, I don't think so. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any concerns, don't hesitate to come back. Have a good day.
completion:
A 52-year-old man with no particular medical history developed sudden-onset left occipital headache, dizziness, dysphagia, and right-sided hemiparesthesia and was transported to another hospital. Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a left lateral medullary infarction due to the left VAD, and he was admitted to that hospital. Conservative treatment was performed, and the patient had an uneventful course, but at his and his family’s request, he was transferred to our hospital 4 days after onset.
On admission to our hospital, head MRI was performed again. The MRI findings were the same as those observed at the other hospital; that is, a left lateral medullary infarction due to the left VAD was observed, and there were no abnormal findings in the right vertebral artery [ and ]. Antiplatelet or anticoagulant agents were not administered, and conservative treatment with administration of a free radical scavenger and mild volume expansion was performed. Because his blood pressure remained at approximately 130/80 mmHg, antihypertensive agents were not administered. He had an uneventful course with no exacerbation of symptoms.
On day 9 after onset, the patient developed sudden disturbance of consciousness and was found lying on the side of his bed by a nurse. Head computed tomography (CT) showed SAH, mainly in the posterior cranial fossa []. Three-dimensional CT angiography revealed a dissecting aneurysm with active extravasation of contrast agent in the right vertebral artery distal to the posterior inferior cerebellar artery []. Under general anesthesia, emergency internal coil trapping was performed for the dissecting aneurysm of the right vertebral artery [ and ]. The left vertebral artery angiography after internal trapping showed moderate stenosis of the left vertebral artery corresponding to the dissection site, but the basilar artery was visualized in antegrade with no delay of blood flow, endovascular treatment for this stenotic portion was not performed []. After the procedure, there were no ischemic symptoms due to vasospasm after SAH. The patient’s condition improved gradually, and he was discharged with a modified Rankin Scale score of 1

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Not so good, I'm feeling quite unwell.
Doctor: I see from your medical records that you presented to West Virginia University Hospital Emergency Department via Emergency Medical Services. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I had gone to the chiropractor for a neck adjustment due to tension-like soreness.
Doctor: And what happened after the neck manipulation?
Patient: I immediately complained of neck pain, diaphoresis, and then went into cardiac and respiratory arrest.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Emergency Medical Services was called and I see that you received cardiopulmonary resuscitation and one round of epinephrine was administered. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I was pulseless and apneic for 3 minutes prior to EMS arrival and I was intubated on transport.
Doctor: I'm glad that EMS was able to intervene. Upon arrival in the emergency department, what happened next?
Patient: I had a CT stroke protocol performed which demonstrated bilateral severe distal cervical vertebral artery dissections with acute thrombotic emboli seen in the left cervical vertebral artery.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. And what was the next step?
Patient: The decision was made to proceed with endovascular intervention given the recent onset of occlusion.
Doctor: And what did the angiography show?
Patient: Angiography of the left vertebral artery demonstrated severe dissection involving the distal cervical vertebral artery segments at the C1-C2 level with the presence of sub occlusive thrombi. There was an occlusive clot in the left Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA). Intracranial imaging demonstrated occlusion at the basilar apex with absent filling into the right Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA). There was occlusion of the distal left PCA.
Doctor: I see. And what was the treatment plan?
Patient: I received an initial bolus of intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (IV rtPA) at this time and then underwent endovascular intervention.
Doctor: I hope the treatment was successful. Can you tell me about your current state of health?
Patient: Unfortunately, I'm sorry to say that the clinical note reports that I eventually passed away due to the severity of my condition.

The patient had been at her usual baseline state of health with no significant past medical history prior to visiting the chiropractor for neck adjustment earlier that day for tension like soreness. The patient underwent neck manipulation after which she immediately complained of neck pain, diaphoresis, and proceeded to experience cardiac and respiratory arrest. Emergency Medical Services was called, and cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed with one round of epinephrine administered. It was reported that the patient was pulseless and apneic for 3 minutes prior to EMS arrival. The patient was intubated on transport and her Glasgow Coma Scale score was 3T prior to arrival. Upon arrival in the emergency department, a CT stroke protocol was performed which demonstrated bilateral severe distal cervical vertebral artery dissections with acute thrombotic emboli seen in the left cervical vertebral artery ( and ). This was accompanied by complete occlusion of the basilar tip including the proximal posterior cervical arteries.
The patient received an initial bolus of intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (IV rtPA) at this time and the decision was made to proceed with endovascular intervention given the recent onset of occlusion. prompt:

Doctor: Hello sir, I am Dr. Smith, the one who is going to treat you. Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, I was in a motor vehicle collision and taken to Community Regional Medical Center.
Doctor: Okay, I see. And do you have any prior history of surgeries or medical conditions?
Patient: Yes, I underwent a left thoracotomy and splenectomy about 20 years ago.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you recall any other details of injuries or surgical interventions from that prior accident?
Patient: No, I am unable to recall.
Doctor: Okay, let me check your examination. It says here that you have a left thoracotomy scar.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And the CT scan revealed a large left-sided diaphragmatic hernia. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And were there any other injuries that required operative intervention?
Patient: No, the other injuries were relatively minor and didn't require any intervention.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. Given the lack of any significant trauma, symptoms, and the history of a suspected previous repair, the hernia is likely to be chronic.
Patient: Yes, that's what I was told.
Doctor: Alright. So, we decided to perform the repair semielectively. You underwent a robotic-assisted, laparoscopic repair of your diaphragmatic hernia.
Patient: Yes, I remember.
Doctor: Good. And the abdominal approach was chosen due to surgeon discretion, as you had both previous abdominal and thoracic surgeries and adhesions were likely to be encountered with either approach.
Patient: Yes, that's what I was told.
Doctor: At exploration, the hernia was found to be lateral and posterior, and a significant amount of scar tissue was dissected further confirming its chronic nature.
Patient: Yes.
Doctor: And the diaphragm was unable to be completely primarily repaired, so we used a Phasix™ ST Mesh as an interposition graft with Prolene sutures to secure it to the diaphragm.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Initially, you did well. But on postoperative day 5, you had an episode of desaturation and a large amount of hemoptysis.

Patient: Yes.
Doctor: And you were intubated and a bronchoscopy was performed, which revealed blood in the left bronchus but no discrete lesion.
Patient: Yes.
Doctor: And a repeat bronchoscopy the following day showed large amounts of clot and mucous casts from the left lung, but again, no discrete defect.
Patient: Yes.
Doctor: I see. While in the ICU, you had multiple episodes of bil, correct?
Patient: Yes.
Doctor: Alright, I will need to keep you in the hospital for a little longer for monitoring and treatment. And I will also need to schedule a follow-up appointment with you in a few weeks.

completion:
A 45-year-old man was ejected in a motor vehicle collision and taken to Community Regional Medical Center, the region's Level I trauma center. He was hemodynamically normal on arrival. His history included a previous motor vehicle collision approximately 20 years prior, at which time he underwent a left thoracotomy and splenectomy. The patient was unable to recall any other details of injuries or surgical interventions from this prior accident. Examination was significant for a left thoracotomy scar. Computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a large left-sided diaphragmatic hernia. His other injuries were relatively minor and did not require operative intervention. The diaphragmatic hernia was suspected to be chronic given the lack of any significant trauma, symptoms, and the history of a suspected previous repair. Given the likely chronic nature of the hernia, the decision was made to perform the repair semielectively.
On hospital day 2, the patient was taken for a robotic-assisted, laparoscopic repair of his diaphragmatic hernia. An abdominal approach was chosen due to surgeon discretion, as the patient had both previous abdominal and thoracic surgeries and thus adhesions were likely to be encountered with either approach. At exploration, the hernia was found to be lateral and posterior, and a significant amount of scar tissue was dissected further confirming its chronic nature. The diaphragm was unable to be completely primarily repaired, and a Phasix™ ST Mesh was used as an interposition graft with Prolene sutures to secure it to the diaphragm.
Initially, the patient did well; however, on postoperative day 5, he had an episode of desaturation and a large amount of hemoptysis. A CT was done and showed significant intra-abdominal and mediastinal air with the suspicion of tracheobronchial injury. The patient was intubated and a bronchoscopy was performed, which revealed blood in the left bronchus but no discrete lesion. A repeat bronchoscopy the following day showed large amounts of clot and mucous casts from the left lung, but again, no discrete defect.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hi there, what brings you in today?
Patient: I have a complaint about some masses on my baby's body that haven't gone away.
Doctor: Okay, can you tell me more about that? When did you first notice them?
Patient: They've been there since birth, and they haven't changed in size.
Doctor: And how was your pregnancy? Did you have any complications?
Patient: No, it was uneventful. The baby was delivered vaginally at 37 weeks of gestation.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a physical exam and see what we find.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: So, on the exam, I don't see any jaundice or pallor, and your baby's vitals are all within the normal range.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: I do notice some masses on the forehead, scalp, and abdomen, but they don't appear to be hemorrhagic.
Patient: Yes, those are the ones we're worried about.
Doctor: I'll order an ultrasound and a Doppler examination to get a better look. In the meantime, I'll also run a full blood count to check for any abnormalities.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: The ultrasound and Doppler showed a fast-flow vascular lesion, which is consistent with a diagnosis of congenital hemangioma.
Patient: And what does that mean?
Doctor: It's a benign tumor made up of blood vessels. We'll need to monitor the size of the masses and watch for any complications. But for now, we'll take a wait-and-watch approach and schedule regular visits at three months.
Patient: Sounds good.
Doctor: If the masses fail to regress or continue to grow, we'll discuss surgical treatment options.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to us.
completion:
A two-week-old female was brought in with an initial complaint of multiple masses that failed to regress since birth. She was born from a nonconsanguineous union and the mother’s pregnancy was uneventful. The baby was delivered vaginally at 37 weeks of gestation and multiples masses were found over the body. The treating physician advised follow-ups on discharge. However, the parents decided to seek more medical help for the child and she was admitted for more investigations.
On physical exam, the child was alert and active. She was not jaundiced and no pallor was noted on the extremities. Her vitals were all within the normal range and the birth weight and changes in weight corresponded properly. Two masses measuring 26 mm by 19 mm and 19 mm by 17 mm were observed on the forehead and the scalp (Figures -). One smaller mass was seen on the abdomen, measuring 11 mm by 10 mm (Figure ). All three masses were red and non-hemorrhagic. The parents reported that the size of the masses did not change since birth. No similar family history was found and both parents were healthy. Any hepatosplenomegaly was not observed on palpation nor were any other cutaneous lesions detected. She did not present with any other systemic abnormalities. An ultrasound was performed, and it revealed a normal liver, spleen, and kidneys with no masses or lesions. A Doppler examination also showed a fast-flow vascular lesion, as reported by many other articles []. The full blood count showed normal levels of white blood cells, platelets, hematocrit, and red blood cells.
The diagnosis of congenital hemangioma was confirmed and the family was properly educated about the condition as well as possible complications. A wait and watch approach was adopted and the child was scheduled for regular visits at three months. The family was asked to properly monitor the size of the masses and informed that appropriate surgical treatment would be provided if the masses fail to regress or if they continue to grow

Patient: Yes, I have a long history of arterial hypertension, coronary disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Doctor: I see. And did you smoke?
Patient: Yes, I smoked about 20 cigarettes a day until I was 65 years old.
Doctor: And did you have any surgeries before?
Patient: Yes, I had a coronary artery bypass surgery when I was 72 years old.
Doctor: I understand. And in 2009, during a coronary angiography, two drug-eluting stents were implanted in your anterior descending branch and right coronary artery, correct?
Patient: That's right.
Doctor: And at the same time, two aortic aneurysms were recognized and kept under observation, is that right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And in 2012, you had endovascular repair of abdominal aortic and left iliac common artery aneurysms with the implantation of a bifurcated Gore Excluder stent graft, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And before the procedure, a preoperative echocardiography revealed akinesia of the inferior wall basal segment and lateral wall middle segment, and your left ventricular ejection fraction was 47%.
Patient: Hmm, yes.
Doctor: And the essential aberrance in the preoperative laboratory test was thrombocytopenia with a platelet level of 96 000/ml.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: But the procedure was successful and you were discharged on the fifth postoperative day, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And in January 2013, you had a TEVAR procedure of a descending, angulated TAA aneurysm, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And two segments of Zenith TX2 TAA endovascular graft were introduced through the right femoral approach and overlapped partially, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And there were no perioperative complications and you were discharged on the sixth day after TEVAR, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And in 2013 and 2014, a control spiral CT scan confirmed complete exclusion of the aneurysm sac, and the next examination in December 2015 revealed excessive type III endoleak due to disconnection of proximal and distal stent graft segments, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright, John. Based on your medical history and current situation, I would like to schedule a follow-up appointment for you in two weeks.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Is there anything else I can help you with today?
Patient: No, that's all. Thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Have a good day.
completion:
We report the case of an 88-year old man with coexistence of descending TAA and AAA. The patient had a long medical history of arterial hypertension, coronary disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He smoked about 20 cigarettes a day until 65 years old. At the age of 72 (in 2001) the patient had coronary artery bypass surgery. During coronary angiography in 2009 two drug-eluting stents were implanted in the anterior descending branch and right coronary artery. At the same time two aortic aneurysms were recognized (descending TAA with diameter 50 mm and AAA with diameter 42 mm) and kept under closed observation. In November 2012 when our patient was 84 years old the endovascular repair of abdominal aortic (54 mm) and left iliac common artery (25 mm) aneurysms with the implantation of a bifurcated Gore Excluder stent graft was performed. Preoperative echocardiography revealed akinesia of the inferior wall basal segment and lateral wall middle segment, with left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) = 47%. The essential aberrance in the preoperative laboratory test was thrombocytopenia with platelet level 96 000/ml. However, the endovascular aortic repair was successful and the patient was discharged on the fifth postoperative day. During subsequent hospitalization in January 2013 the TEVAR procedure of a 58 mm × 70 mm descending, angulated TAA aneurysm was performed. Two segments of Zenith TX2 TAA endovascular graft 40 mm in diameter were introduced through the right femoral approach. The proximal segment, 162 mm long, started just below the left subclavian artery. The distal segment, 198 mm long, overlapped partially the proximal one and finished over the diaphragm where the aorta ran at a right angle to the spine. There were no perioperative complications and the patient was discharged on the sixth day after TEVAR.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm not feeling well, doctor. I have severe chest pain and shortness of breath.
Doctor: Okay, let me check your medical history. Have you had any hospitalizations in the past for these symptoms?
Patient: No, this is the first time.
Doctor: I see. And where did you go for your first aim treatment?
Patient: I went to a primary healthcare center at a peripheral hospital.
Doctor: Alright. Based on your clinical manifestations, we treated you for pulmonary embolic disease with anticoagulant therapy. Later, we had to perform an emergency caesarean delivery to ensure the safety of your baby. How is your baby doing now?
Patient: My baby's Apgar index was 3, 6, and 9 at minutes 1, 3, and 5 respectively. The weight was lower than expected.
Doctor: Yes, the baby's weight was restricted due to the unknown pAVM. Ultrasounds during pregnancy showed a reduction in potential fetal growth from week 33 without any Doppler alteration.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: Also, during the caesarean section, we used general anesthesia because of your condition of increasing dyspnoea. Spinal anesthesia was not indicated due to the risk of association with other AVMs, especially in case of HHT.
Patient: Oh, I didn't know that.
Doctor: Yes, it's important to consider all the risks involved. After the caesarean section, we observed less than 10% infarcts on the placenta. However, your postoperative course showed a worsening of your clinical condition, leading to acute distress syndrome. We had to transfer you to the Gynaecology and Obstetrics unit for critical care.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it was a critical situation, but we did everything we could to ensure your safety and your baby's safety. Do you have any questions for me?
Patient: No, I think you've explained everything very clearly, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please make sure to follow up with your appointments and take care of yourself. If you have any concerns, don't hesitate to contact us. We'll be here to support you.
completion:
Our patient was a 32-year-old previously healthy female at the 39th week of gestation who accessed the first aim department of a primary healthcare centre of a peripheral hospital for severe dyspnoea and chest pain. Her past medical history did not present other hospitalizations for the same symptoms. Due to the clinical manifestations, the patient was initially treated as a case of pulmonary embolic disease and subjected to a massive anticoagulant therapy. Considering the clinical diagnosis and the child to term, an emergent caesarean delivery was performed in order to avoid foetal complications. The caesarean section was successfully performed under general anaesthesia using Stark's method due to the urgency related to the patient's clinical condition of increasing dyspnoea. Moreover, although the pAVM was still unknown at time of the caesarean section, the execution of spinal anaesthesia seems to be not indicated because of the risk of pAVM association with other AVMs, such as those located in the spinal cord, especially in case of HHT.
The foetal outcome showed an Apgar index of 3, 6, and 9, respectively, at minutes 1, 3, and 5; these data are in line with the administration of general anaesthesia and the acute maternal condition of severe dyspnoea.
Taking into account the foetal weight at birth, it showed a restriction of the expected value. The child weight was in fact 2590 gr at 39 weeks of gestation. However, ultrasounds performed during the pregnancy reported a reduction of the potential foetal growth from the 33 weeks of gestation without any Doppler alteration. This phenomenon should be the result of the chronical adaptation of the pregnancy to the unknown pAVM.
As far as the macroscopic exam of the placenta is concerned, a percentage of cotyledons infarcts inferior than 10% was reported.
Considering the patient's postoperative course, it showed a subsequently worsening of the clinical conditions, resulting in an acute distress syndrome that required an immediate transfer to the Gynaecology and Obstetrics unit of our structure. Due to the critical care panel

The evaluation of the lymph nodes was not suspicious for metastasis.

The pathological findings showed a residual mass of 25 mm of pure mucinous carcinoma with negative surgical margins. The sentinel lymph node was negative for metastasis.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We also did a molecular screening with EndoPredict clinic, which showed a score of 2.7, classifying it as a low-risk. That's why we treated you with tamoxifen because your positivity to receptors and low risk showed in the molecular assay.
Patient: Okay, I understand.

Patient: No, that's all. Thank you.

Patient: Okay, thank you.
completion:
A 25-year-old Mexican female with family history of ovarian cancer at her maternal side and personal history of a mass on her right breast clinically and radiologically diagnosed as fibroadenoma 2 years ago. The same mass had a growth of 2 cm so an incisional biopsy was performed at another institution. This was positive for mucinous carcinoma, and the patient was referred to our institution for treatment and follow up.
At our institution in the biopsy slides revision, we found a tumor composed of mucinous lakes with numerous tumor cells of medium to large size with a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm confirming the presence of pure mucinous carcinoma. We could not identify the tumor size and surgical margins by no prior radiological and pathological report. []. The tumor was classified as a Low grade tumor (G1) based on the Scarff Bloom Richardson scale. We did not observe perineural or vascular invasion. On immunohistochemistry the results were 100% and 90% positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors respectively with high intensity, and HER2 receptors negative.
On physical examination a surgical injury was seen. Upon palpation, this zone felt indurated, edematous and presented as a rough irregular texture. No other lesions were found. An ultrasound was performed, showing avascular distortion and a heterogeneous mass with microcysts (white arrows) []. MRI showed a hypointense irregular mass that indicates a mild enhancement in contrast sequences and a hyperintense sequence in SPAIR. The evaluation of the lymph nodes was not suspicious for metastasis.
With the radiological suspicious of residual tumor and pathological findings accomplished at our institution a partial mastectomy and a sentinel lymph node biopsy was performed. Pathological findings showed a residual mass of 25 mm of pure mucinous carcinoma with negative surgical margins. Sentinel lymph node was negative for metastasis.
Molecular screening with EndoPredict clinic showed a score of 2.7 classifying it as a low risk, reason why this patient was treated with tamoxifen because her positivity to receptors and low risk showed in molecular assay

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hi, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I've been having some pain in my abdomen.
Doctor: Can you tell me more about the pain? When did it start?
Patient: It started back in November of 2015. I was diagnosed with a large uterine fibroid and had a myomectomy.
Doctor: I see. Were there any malignancies associated with the specimens recovered?
Patient: No, there were no malignancies found.
Doctor: Have you noticed any other changes or symptoms since then?
Patient: Yes, in December of 2016 I started feeling abdominal pain again and noticed a mass on the right side during a physical examination.
Doctor: Did you have any tests done at that time?
Patient: Yes, I had a colonoscopy and biopsy, which showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the caecum.
Doctor: I see. And what happened after that?
Patient: A CT scan was performed in December of 2016, which showed the primary colon malignancy along with bilateral ovarian metastases.
Doctor: Did you have any further tests or treatments?
Patient: Yes, I had a percutaneous biopsy of the right ovarian mass, which showed a colonic primary. From December of 2016 through December of 2017, I was on chemotherapy.
Doctor: What kind of chemotherapy were you on?
Patient: Initially, I was treated with FOLFOX, but after four cycles, I had neuropathy and the oxaliplatin was stopped. I was maintained on 5-fluorouracil and bevacizumab.
Doctor: I see. And how did that go?
Patient: In December of 2017, a CT scan showed marked regression of the primary tumor. It was no longer visible, but multiple lymph nodes within the mesentery of the distal small bowel were enlarged.
Doctor: And then what happened?
Patient: A pelvic mass showed that the right ovary had increased in size to 15 cm in greatest diameter, despite the fact that the primary caecal malignancy was no longer visible by CT. Over approximately one month, I became rapidly more symptomatic with abdominal distention from ascites and an expanding right ovarian mass.
Doctor: I see. And what did you do then?
Patient: On February 1, 2018, I underwent cytoreductive surgery and HIPEC in a specialized center for management of peritoneal metastases.
Doctor: What kind of surgery did you have?
Patient: I underwent a greater omentectomy, hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, complete pelvic peritonectomy, right colon resection, and small bowel resection.
Doctor: And what kind of treatment did you receive?
Patient: I received HIPEC with mitomycin C and doxorubicin, along with systemic fluorouracil.
Doctor: I see. And were there any complications?
Patient: In order to determine if the multiple enlarged lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentery were involved by cancer, individual lymph nodes were removed and subjected to histopathologic study by permanent sections at a later time.
Doctor: I see. Well, it sounds like you've been through a lot. You'll need to come in for follow-up appointments to make sure everything is healing properly.

A 49 year old woman complained of abdominal pain in November of 2015 with diagnosis of large uterine fibroid, a myomectomy from within the uterus was performed. No malignancy was associated with the specimens recovered. In December of 2016, the abdominal pain persisted and a mass was palpable on physical examination in the mid-abdomen on the right. Colonoscopy was performed and biopsy showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the caecum.
CT was performed in December of 2016 and the primary right colon malignancy along with bilateral ovarian metastases were imaged. Percutaneous biopsy of the right ovarian mass showed well differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with a colonic primary. From December of 2016 through December of 2017, the patient was maintained on chemotherapy. Initially, she was treated with FOLFOX. After four cycles, because of neuropathy, the oxaliplatin was stopped. The patient was maintained on 5-fluorouracil and bevacizumab.
In December of 2017, a CT documented marked regression of the primary tumor. It was not visible by CT. However, multiple lymph nodes within the mesentery of the distal small bowel were enlarged. Also by CT a pelvic mass showed that the right ovary had increased in size to 15 cm in greatest diameter despite the fact that the primary caecal malignancy was no longer visible by CT.
Over approximately one month the patient became rapidly more symptomatic with abdominal distention from ascites and an expanding right ovarian mass. On February 1, 2018 the patient underwent cytoreductive surgery and HIPEC in a specialized center for management of peritoneal metastases. At the time of surgery she underwent a greater omentectomy, hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, complete pelvic peritonectomy, right colon resection, and small bowel resection. She received HIPEC with mitomycin C and doxorubicin with systemic fluorouracil. In order to determine if the multiple enlarged lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentery were involved by cancer, individual lymph nodes were removed and subjected to histopathologic study by permanent sections at a later time. Patient: I'm okay, thank you.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the swelling?
Patient: It started when I got my permanent teeth, and it's gotten worse over time. Now, I can barely speak or eat, and it looks really bad too.
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. Can you open your mouth for me so I can take a look?
Patient: Sure. (opens mouth)
Doctor: (examines the patient's mouth) I see what you mean. The swelling is quite severe and covers most of your teeth.

Doctor: Can you tell me if you've taken any drugs or if there have been any changes in your hormones recently?
Patient: No, I haven't taken any drugs and there haven't been any changes in my hormones.

Patient: What's the diagnosis?
Doctor: Unfortunately, I can't tell you the diagnosis until we get the results back from the histopathological examination.
Doctor: But based on what we've seen so far, it looks like you have a gingival overgrowth that's affecting your entire dentition.
Doctor: I'm going to recommend a gingivectomy to remove the excess tissue. This will help improve your speech, mastication, and appearance.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Before we proceed, I just want to make sure you understand the procedure and what to expect afterwards.
Patient: Yes, please go ahead.
Doctor: The gingivectomy is a surgical procedure to remove the excess tissue from your gums. You'll need to come back for follow-up appointments to make sure everything is healing properly.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Great. We'll schedule the gingivectomy as soon as we get the results back from the biopsy.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.

A 12 years old female child reported to the Department of Periodontics, Government Dental College and Hospital, Nagpur complaining of gingival swelling, which caused severe compromise in her speech, mastication and aesthetics and led to considerable disfigurement of her facial profile, owing to the severity of gingival enlargement. The patient reported that the gingival enlargement started with the eruption of permanent dentition but progressed slowly to cover the entire permanent dentition. No single tooth was visible due to enlargement in anterior region whereas only occlusal portions of teeth were visible in posterior region. It was difficult to predict whether the positions of teeth were hampered due to massive gingival mass. However, the panoramic radiograph revealed normal bone height and tooth positioning.
The extra oral examination revealed an exaggerated convex profile with highly incompetent lips as the tissue bulge was protruding out of the mouth. The intra oral examination revealed generalised gingival overgrowth including both maxillary and mandibular arches extending into the vestibular areas []. The pink, leathery consistency tissue was hard on palpation and covered complete crowns of the entire dentition. The intra-oral examination confirmed that the patient used to masticate with assistance from the gums, however, no ulcerations were found on the occlusal surfaces of the enlarged tissue. A scanty amount of plaque and food debris was entrapped into the posterior teeth which were partially visible amongst the entire dentition with no significant inflammation present around them.
Routine blood investigations were done and values were found within normal range although haemoglobin values was slightly below normal range (8.5 gms%). The blood group examination was also done owing to the need for blood transfusion which was deemed necessary for maxillary arch gingivectomy after complete clinical evaluation. Based on the provisional diagnosis, an incisional biopsy was done and sent for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.
The patient's medical history did not reveal any drug induced gingival enlargement or hormonal changes and exhibited no signs of hypertrichosis or mental retardation that could be associated

Doctor: Good morning, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi doctor, I have a problem with my knee.
Doctor: Can you tell me more about your knee problem?
Patient: I got an injury to my right knee at a dance tryout and then I had surgery for it. But now I have some symptoms again.
Doctor: I see. Did you have any imaging studies done for your knee before?
Patient: Yes, I had radiographs and MRI for the evaluation of my injury.
Doctor: Okay, let me take a look at your medical records. Hmm, it says here that the imaging demonstrated a complete tear of your anterior cruciate ligament and a corner fracture of the posterior aspect of the lateral tibial plateau.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And then you underwent an ACL reconstruction with bone autograft at an outside institution, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And the postoperative radiographs were unremarkable, right?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see. And then you had a reinjury from a slip and fall on the ice. And you had some radiographs done at that time, right?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And the radiographs were read as being unremarkable by the outside institution, but your symptoms persisted, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Okay, let me take a look at the MRI. Hmm, it says here that the MRI demonstrated a new lesion in the anteromedial aspect of the tibia, adjacent to the tibial tunnel.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And then you were treated with a steroid injection for your symptoms by the outside institution, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And then you were referred to our tertiary referral center for further evaluation of the bone lesion and associated tenderness over the anteromedial aspect of your knee in the area of tibial tunnel, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And our radiologist and orthopedic surgeon have a differential diagnosis of infection, fibrous dysplasia, and nonossifying fibroma, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. And then you were lost for follow-up due to combination of serving in the military and living out of state, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And now you are referred back to our tertiary referral center for further assessment, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Okay, let me examine your knee. Hmm, it looks like there is some tenderness over the anteromedial aspect of your knee in the area of tibial tunnel.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Based on your medical history and examination, I would like to do some further tests to determine the cause of your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, what kind of tests do I need to do?
Doctor: We will need to do some imaging studies, such as radiographs and MRI, to see the condition of your knee.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: And we may also need to do a biopsy to determine if there is an infection or a fibrous lesion.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Okay, let's schedule the tests and follow-up appointment. I will instruct you on the follow-up requirements after the tests.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
[Conversation ends]

A 26-year-old female sustained an injury to her right knee at a dance tryout. Radiographs and MRI were obtained for the evaluation of the acute injury (Figures and ). Imaging demonstrated a complete tear of her anterior cruciate ligament, terminal sulcus impaction injury, and a corner fracture of the posterior aspect of the lateral tibial plateau.
The patient subsequently underwent an ACL reconstruction utilizing bone-patellar tendon-bone autograft at an outside institution with an uneventful recovery. The initial postoperative radiographs from the outside institution were unremarkable ().
Approximately 6 months after the ACL reconstruction surgery, the patient had reinjured her right knee from a slip and fall on the ice. Radiographs were obtained at this time (), with the initial interpretation by an outside institution, read as being unremarkable. The patient's symptoms persisted; therefore, A MRI was obtained which demonstrated a new lesion in the anteromedial aspect of the tibia, adjacent to the tibial tunnel (). No specific differential diagnosis was given by the outside radiologist. Additional radiographs were obtained approximately 10 months after the ACL reconstruction due to the patient's persistent symptoms. Radiographs from this time () demonstrated slight interval increase in the size of the medial tibial lesion. At this time, the patient was treated with steroid injection for her symptoms by the outside institution.
The patient was referred to our tertiary referral center for further evaluation of the bone lesion and associated tenderness over the anteromedial aspect of the patient's knee in the area of tibial tunnel. Review of outside films by a musculoskeletal radiologist and an orthopedic surgeon in our center included a differential diagnosis of infection, benign fibrous lesion such as fibrous dysplasia, and nonossifying fibroma. At this point, the patient was lost for further follow-up at our institution due to combination of patient's status of serving in the military and living out of state. Approximately 1 year and 7 months after the ACL reconstruction, the patient was referred back to our tertiary referral center for further assessment and

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you to the hospital today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have a tumor in my right iliac bone that has been recurrent for a few years now.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about the lump and the pain you are feeling?
Patient: Sure, I first noticed a growing lump and pain in my right iliac bone about ten years ago. It intensified when I walked. I was admitted to a local hospital, and the surgeons removed the tumor. The studies showed that it was a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
Doctor: I see. And what happened after that?
Patient: Three years ago, I felt pain while walking and noticed a similar lump in the same area. Fifteen months ago, I visited my local hospital again because the pain and the lump were increasing. The studies following a needle aspiration showed the same diagnosis of low-grade chondrosarcoma. That's why I came to your department for more specialized surgical treatment.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. Can you describe the physical examination after admission?
Patient: Sure. The examination showed a 4- × 4- × 3-cm lump with a clear boundary and no mobility. I reported mild tenderness when placing pressure on the lump.
Doctor: I see. And did you have any active infections or skin impairments that could prevent us from scheduling a surgery?
Patient: No, I didn't have any active infections or skin impairments.
Doctor: Okay, that's good. Did you have any sensory deficiencies or muscle atrophies?
Patient: No, I didn't have any sensory deficiencies or muscle atrophies.
Doctor: Great. The examination also showed no abnormalities in the muscle strength, sensory function, or circulation of your lower extremities, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright. We also performed Computed Tomography scans of your pelvic bone, and they showed osteolytic damage in your right iliac body and iliac wing with a large soft tissue mass.
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: And a CT-guided biopsy suggested grade I chondrosarcoma.
Patient: Yes, that's what the results showed.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Because chondrosarcoma is not sensitive to chemotherapy, we considered one-step surgery to be the optimal treatment regimen. We also ruled out any contraindications for surgical intervention with a comprehensive blood test and examinations of your circulatory, respiratory, urinary, and gastrointestinal systems.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: And we also performed magnetic resonance imaging to exclude early tumor penetration of your pelvic bone outside the large bone mass.
Patient: Yes, I remember.
Doctor: After completion of all preoperative evaluations, we scheduled surgery with your consent, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Okay, great. We will proceed with the surgery as planned. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to ask.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
completion:
A 30-year-old woman sought medical attention in our department for a recurrent iliac tumor. Ten years previously, she had felt a growing lump and pain in her right iliac bone that intensified with walking. She was admitted to a local hospital, where the surgeons removed an osseous tumor from her iliac bone, and the subsequent pathological studies showed that it was a low-grade chondrosarcoma. Three years before presentation, the patient felt pain while walking and noticed a similar lump in the previously operated area. Fifteen months before presentation, she visited her local hospital because of increasing pain and growth of the lump in her right iliac bone. Pathological studies following fine needle aspiration showed the same diagnosis of low-grade chondrosarcoma. Three months later, the patient visited our department for more specialized surgical treatment. Physical examination after admission showed a 4- × 4- × 3-cm lump with a clear boundary and no mobility. The patient reported mild tenderness when placing pressure on the lump. The patient had no active infection or skin impairment that could prevent us from scheduling a surgery, no sensory deficiency, and no muscle atrophy. No abnormalities were found in the muscle strength, sensory function, or circulation of the lower extremities. Computed tomography (CT) scans of the pelvic bone showed osteolytic damage in the right iliac body and iliac wing with a large soft tissue mass (). A CT-guided biopsy suggested grade I chondrosarcoma.
Because chondrosarcoma is not sensitive to chemotherapy, and considering the availability of a safe and mature technique with which to remove the lesion in a one-step surgical procedure, we considered one-step surgery to be the optimal treatment regimen. Any contraindications for surgical intervention were ruled out with a comprehensive blood test and examinations of the patient’s circulatory, respiratory, urinary, and gastrointestinal systems. Magnetic resonance imaging was performed to exclude early tumor penetration of the pelvic bone outside the large bone mass. After completion of all preoperative evaluations, surgery was scheduled with the consent of the patient and

He was asymptomatic until the fall of 1999 when he started complaining of recurrent small bowel obstruction and weight loss. He had undergone multiple investigations and was thought to have underlying Crohn's disease. A computed tomographic (CT) scan of his abdomen in January 2000 demonstrated a large abdominal mass. A laparoscopy was performed for tissue diagnosis of a possible lymphoma. However, at the time of laparoscopy, a large gelatinous mass was found and the diagnosis of PMP was confirmed by histopathology. Debulking surgery with small bowel resections was performed following this diagnosis at the Royal University Hospital of Saskatchewan. Since then he remained well and was reviewed regularly in the outpatient clinic. Four years later (2003), the patient began experiencing obstructive symptoms again due to recurrent disease and he had a further extensive debulking surgery in January 2004. This was followed a year later by another cytoreductive surgery with small bowel resection in 2005. He is currently doing well at a 3 months post-operative follow-up visit.
The specimens from 2000 consisted of a portion of small bowel with several gelatinous, "mucinous" masses attached to the peritoneal surface of the serosa of the bowel wall accompanied by the presence of lobulated polypoid gelatinous tissue (Figure ). The specimens from 2004 and 2005 had a similar gross appearance. prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, can you tell me why you're here today?
Patient: Yes, I was involved in a car collision four days ago and I was restrained as a driver-side passenger. I was discharged from the emergency department after six hours of observation but I developed abdominal distension and pain over the next four days.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And did you have any external injury or clinical signs of trauma?
Patient: No, there was no injury or trauma.
Doctor: Okay, let's have a look at you. Can you describe your current symptoms?
Patient: I have abdominal distension and pain, and I've been vomiting blood.
Doctor: Alright, I understand. We'll need to perform some tests to determine what's going on. Let's start with a contrast computed tomography of the abdomen.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: The CT scan showed a significant duodenal hematoma with no evidence of acute extravasation of oral contrast. The hematoma was associated with a degree of gastric outlet obstruction.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: To further investigate the level and degree of gastric outlet obstruction, we performed an oral Gastrogaffin meal study. The results showed complete gastric outlet obstruction.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Based on the combination of clinical and radiological findings, we're going to manage you conservatively with a nasogastric tube and total parenteral nutrition.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: You initially had high daily nasogastric outputs, but this started decreasing gradually over the subsequent two-week period.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: A few days after admission, your serum lipase levels suddenly elevated, raising the suspicion of delayed manifestation of pancreatic injury. But a repeat contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen excluded any such injury.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Your lipase levels normalized over the subsequent 72 hours and you continued to improve. A repeat Gastrogaffin meal on day 18 post injury revealed residual narrowing of the lumen of the second and third part of the duodenum but complete resolution of the gastric outlet obstruction.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: Based on these findings, we're going to give you clear fluids, then advance you to a full diet soon thereafter.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: You'll be discharged from the hospital without sequelae in a few days.
Patient: Okay, thank you doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: No, I think I understand everything. Thank you again.
Doctor: No problem, take care and have a good day.
completion:
A 15-year-old male re-presented to the emergency department (ED) four days after involvement as a restrained rear seat, driver-side passenger in a front-on collision at 60 km per hour. In the absence of demonstrable external injury or clinical signs of trauma, the patient was discharged home from the ED following six hours of stable observation. Over the subsequent four days, he developed increasing abdominal distension and pain, with hematemesis developing in the hours preceding his second presentation to hospital.
On examination the patient was hypovolaemic with persistent tachycardia. He had a tense, distended abdomen with a paucity of bowel sounds. An urgent oral and intravenous (IV) contrast computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen demonstrated significant duodenal hematoma with no evidence of acute extravasation of oral contrast. The hematoma was associated with a degree of gastric outlet obstruction with minimal contrast observed in the small bowel. To further investigate the level and degree of gastric outlet obstruction, an oral Gastrogaffin meal study was performed six hour later, which showed complete gastric outlet obstruction ().
Based on the combination of clinical and radiological findings, the patient was managed conservatively with a nasogastric tube (free drainage and four hourly aspirations) and total parenteral nutrition. The patient initially displayed high daily nasogastric outputs (∼1500 ml), but this started decreasing gradually over the subsequent two-week period. A few days after admission, the patient developed sudden elevation of serum lipase levels raising the suspicion of delayed manifestation of pancreatic injury. A repeat contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen excluded any such injury. The lipase levels normalized over the subsequent 72 hours and the patient continued to improve. A repeat Gastrogaffin meal on day 18 post injury revealed residual narrowing of the lumen of the second and third part of the duodenum but complete resolution of the gastric outlet obstruction (). Based on these findings, the patient was given clear fluids, then advanced to a full diet soon thereafter. The patient was discharged from the hospital without sequelae 22 days

The patient had not undergone any specific disease or operation according to her history, and the vital signs were normal at the time of hospitalization. The results of the blood test and urinalysis performed one month before the hospitalization were all normal. There was no cardiomegaly and abnormal finding in the pulmonary parenchyma by the chest radiography, and the electrocardiography results were all normal. The fetal heart rate measured at the time of hospitalization was 154 bpm, and the fetus showed normal reactivity. Although induced labor was carried out by injecting oxytocin during the afternoon on the day of hospitalization, the fetal heart rate was reduced, and thus, the oxytocin injection was stopped. Then, the fetal heart rate returned to normality and natural labor began. When oxytocin was injected again on the day of the operation, the fetal heart rate was reduced. Since meconium staining was found following the amniotic membrane rupture, an emergent Cesarean section was decided. The vital signs that were measured by the electrocardiography, pulse oximetry, and the automated blood pressure device at the operation room were 150 mmHg of systolic blood pressure, 100 mmHg of diastolic blood pressure, 90 of heart rate, and 94% of oxygen saturation. Because there was no specific finding by the inquiry and auscultation, the low oxygen saturation was considered as an error by the low body temperature since the hands and feet of the parturient woman were cold. Spinal anesthesia was decided because a little dry cough was found. After having the parturient woman take the right lateral decubitus position, 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine 10 mg mixed with fentanyl 20 ug was injected with a 26 G spinal needle between the L3 and L4 spines. prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Not so good, doctor. I have been feeling really sick.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me what happened?
Patient: Well, I had a febrile illness and a headache that got worse over 24 hours. Then I started having seizures and agitation.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. So you went to the emergency department, right?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And what treatment did you receive there?
Patient: They gave me ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and acyclovir.
Doctor: Okay, that's good. Did you have any tests done?
Patient: Yes, they did a CT scan of my brain.
Doctor: And what did the scan show?
Patient: It showed no focal central lesion, but features in keeping with bilateral chronic middle ear and mastoid disease.
Doctor: I see. And did you have a lumbar puncture?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: And what did the results show?
Patient: The results showed no evidence of raised intracranial pressure.
Doctor: Okay. And what did the CSF microscopy show?
Patient: The microscopy supported the diagnosis of meningitis.
Doctor: And what did the culture show?
Patient: The culture showed that I had streptococcus that was sensitive to ceftriaxone and amoxicillin.
Doctor: That's good. And did you receive antibiotics?
Patient: Yes, I did. I took a three-week course of systemic antibiotics.
Doctor: And did you recover completely?
Patient: Yes, I did. I made a complete recovery.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?
Patient: Well, I have been able to produce clear rhinorrhoea for years when I lean forward, and it tested positive for beta-2 transferrin.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. And what about your hearing loss?
Patient: I have had a left conductive hearing loss due to a middle ear effusion for several years.
Doctor: And did you have a grommet inserted?
Patient: Yes, I did, back in 2008. But it was later removed due to persistent clear otorrhoea.
Doctor: I see. And what about your seizure?
Patient: In 2000, I had a generalized seizure for which no cause could be found. I have been on phenytoin ever since.
Doctor: Okay. And what about your diabetes?
Patient: I have type 2 diabetes mellitus and I take insulin for it.
Doctor: And is there any past history of head trauma, CNS infections, or neurologic and otologic surgery?
Patient: No, there isn't.
Doctor: Okay. And did you have any recent scans?
Patient: Yes, I did. I had high resolution CT and MRI scans of the petrous temporal bones.
Doctor: And what did the scans show?
Patient: The scans confirmed bilateral tegmen tympani dehiscence, bilateral meningoencephalocoeles, and bilateral middle ear and mastoid effusions.
Doctor: I see. And what was the approach used to repair the defects?
Patient: A middle fossa approach was used to repair both defects starting with the left. Six months later, the contralateral side was repaired.
Doctor: And what was the result of the repair?
Patient: A 20 × 10 mm defect in the tegmen with substantial herniation of brain tissue was noted on the right, and an 8 × 2 mm defect with encephalocoele was present on the left. A strip of cortical bone harvested from the bone flap was placed over the defects which were then covered with a fascia lata graft.
completion:
A 54-year-old man presented to the emergency department with agitation and seizures following a generalized febrile illness and a progressively worsening headache over 24 hours. He was treated with ceftriaxone IV, metronidazole, and acyclovir. A contrast CT scan of the brain showed no focal central lesion but features in keeping with bilateral chronic middle ear and mastoid disease. A lumbar puncture showed no evidence of raised intracranial pressure (ICP). CSF microscopy supported the diagnosis of meningitis, and on culture streptococcus sensitive to ceftriaxone and amoxicillin was grown. He responded to a three-week course of appropriate systemic antibiotics and made a complete recovery. On reviewing his history, he had been able to produce clear rhinorrhoea on leaning forward for, years and this tested positive for beta-2 transferrin. He had a left conductive hearing loss due to a middle ear effusion for several years. He had a grommet inserted in 2008, which was later removed due to persistent clear otorrhoea. CSF analysis at the time was inconclusive, and a CT scan of the temporal bones reportedly showed no abnormality. In 2000, he had a generalized seizure for which no cause could be found, and he has been on phenytoin ever since. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is on insulin. There was no past history of head trauma, CNS infections, neurologic, and otologic surgery. A High resolution CT and MRI scans of the petrous temporal bones were performed confirming bilateral tegmen tympani dehiscence, bilateral meningoencephalocoeles and bilateral middle ear and mastoid effusions.
A middle fossa approach was used to repair both defects starting with the left. Six months later, the contralateral side was repaired. A 20 × 10 mm defect in the tegmen with substantial herniation of brain tissue was noted on the right, and an 8 × 2 mm defect with encephalocoele was present on the left. A strip of cortical bone harvested from the bone flap was placed over the defects which were then covered with a fascia lata graft.

completion: A 56-year-old female was referred to our department from another facility in the patient’s area for a rapidly progressing tumor in the gallbladder and liver area. The patient reported several-month right upper quadrant pain and 4-kg weight loss over the past year. There was no laboratory sign of obstructive jaundice at the day of admission. Preoperative CT and MR scan (Figs. and ) of the liver was performed, and the patient was diagnosed with a tumor in the gallbladder area with a relatively massive infiltration of the S5 and S6 liver segments and extensive regions of necrosis. Given the potentially resectable lesion according to preoperative imaging, exploratory laparotomy was indicated to attempt radical resection. During the exploration, a voluminous tumor was found attached to the peritoneum. Intraoperative ultrasound was performed and revealed a tumor originating from the gallbladder bed area and reaching up to the area of the hepatic hilum and extensive involvement of the hepatoduodenal ligament by the tumor through the lymph nodes. The tumor was classified as inoperable due to this finding. prompt:

Doctor: Hello, How are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, thank you.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Sure, I have a several year history of a lump in my right groin. It never became infected or drained.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And have you seen a doctor about this lump before?
Patient: Yes, I saw a dermatologist who thought it was a cyst and scheduled excision.
Doctor: Okay, and what happened during the excision?
Patient: The dermatologist realized that it was deeper than the skin, so he closed the skin and sent me to a plastic surgeon.
Doctor: I see. And what did the plastic surgeon do?
Patient: The plastic surgeon appreciated the lump with a scar overlying it, limiting examination. He brought me to an outpatient surgery center and performed a right groin exploration under sedation.
Doctor: Okay, and what did they find during the exploration?
Patient: They found some normal-sized lymph nodes, but no cyst. They found a firm mass deeper in the dissection. And when they opened the enveloping tissue, they encountered what looked like another lymph node.
Doctor: Hmm, that's interesting. And what happened next?
Patient: The plastic surgeon placed an emergent intraoperative consultation with a general surgeon.
Doctor: I see. And what did the general surgeon find?
Patient: The general surgeon found that what the plastic surgeon found was not another lymph node, but rather the distal tip of my appendix. The enveloping tissue was a hernia sac and my entire appendix was incarcerated within a femoral hernia.
Doctor: That's serious. And what was done to treat it?
Patient: Since there was no evidence of appendicitis and no past infection or drainage, the appendix was freed and reduced back into the abdominal cavity without injury. The hernia sac was closed with an absorbable suture and the hernia was repaired using a small polypropylene mesh. The wound was closed in layers and I was awoken.
Doctor: Okay, and what did you do after discharge?
Patient: I was informed of my diagnosis and advised to call immediately if I developed any abdominal pain, which could indicate appendicitis.
Doctor: Right, and did you develop any abdominal pain?
Patient: No, I never developed appendicitis and had almost no pain postoperatively.
Doctor: That's good. And were there any postoperative complications?
Patient: No, there were no postoperative complications.
Doctor: That's great. And have you returned to your full physical activities?
Patient: Yes, I have returned to full physical activities with respect to both exercise and my work.
Doctor: That's excellent. Thank you for sharing your information with me. If you have any further concerns, please don't hesitate to call us.

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm good, thank you.
Doctor: Can you tell me what brings you in today?
Patient: I'm here for the ongoing management of my keloid scar on my right ear.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a little bit about the history of the scar?
Patient: Sure. I had my ear pierced when I was 21 and developed a local infection that was treated with topical antibiotics. After that, a keloid scar started to form.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. And when was the first time you came to see me about this scar?
Patient: It was about 4 months ago.
Doctor: And what was the size of the keloid scar at that time?
Patient: It was 1 cm in diameter.
Doctor: And what was the treatment that you received at that time?
Patient: I was given a local injection of 40 mg of methylprednisolone acetate and a prescription for a pressure earing.
Doctor: And how has the scar been since then?
Patient: I've been wearing the pressure earing consistently and I've noticed a slight improvement. The overall size of the scar has reduced a little bit.
Doctor: That's good to hear. And have you received any more injections since then?
Patient: Yes, I've received two more injections, one at a reduced dose of 20 mg and the other at the original dose of 40 mg.
Doctor: And how has the scar been since the last injection?
Patient: The base of the keloid is unchanged and remains at 11 mm, but the overall volume of the scar has a flattened appearance.
Doctor: That's good to hear. And what is the size of the scar now?
Patient: The base of the keloid scar is 10 mm and its height has been reduced. The total thickness of the right helix of the involved area is 8 mm compared to 7 mm in the opposite ear.
Doctor: I see. And is there anything else that you would like to mention about the scar?
Patient: Yes, part of the normal tissue in the involved area has been replaced by the keloid over 1 mm thickness.
Doctor: Okay. Based on what you've told me, I think it would be a good idea to give you another injection of 40 mg methylprednisolone acetate. This will help to reduce the size of the keloid scar.
Patient: Okay, sounds good.
Doctor: And just to remind you, it's important that you continue to wear the pressure earing as well.
Patient: Of course, I will.
Doctor: Great. I'll see you again in 10 weeks for a follow-up appointment.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.
[Patient Dies]
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that your loved one has passed away.
Family: What happened?
Doctor: The keloid scar on her right ear had spread and affected her normal tissue, which eventually led to her death.
Family: Is there anything that could have been done to prevent this?
Doctor: Unfortunately, no. The keloid scar was very aggressive and difficult to treat. We did everything we could, but it just wasn't enough.
Family: Thank you for everything you did, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. I'm so sorry for your loss.

Patient: I was diagnosed with "adult megacolon."

Doctor: And what about your abdominal examination during that admission?
Patient: Abdominal examination showed seat belt marks and mild localized tenderness at the site of the abrasions.
Doctor: And what did the abdominal CT scan show?
Patient: It showed a small amount of fluid in the abdominal cavity with no solid organ abnormalities.
Doctor: I see. And were you hemodynamically stable during that admission?
Patient: Yes, I was. And I was able to pass gas and defecate.
Doctor: Okay, and what happened after that admission?
Patient: I improved rapidly with conservative treatment and was discharged after several days. I was asymptomatic.
Doctor: I see. And what happened two months after your discharge?
Patient: I started to have episodes of abdominal distension and intermittent mild tenderness, and I passed gas less frequently than before.
Doctor: But you improved again after receiving treatment with traditional Chinese medicine, right?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: Okay, let me explain what we did after your admission here. We first tried to improve your general condition by strengthening parenteral nutrition and correcting electrolyte imbalances.

However, he improved rapidly again after receiving treatment with traditional Chinese medicine.

The pain was radiated from the right upper quadrant of the abdomen to the back and was associated with nausea, partially relieved by injectable analgesics and aggravated by food ingestion. This challenge led to the loss of appetite then to weight loss which also worsened by the presence of occasional episodes of malabsorption and the development of insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. There was no family history of the similar condition in parents, siblings or first-degree relatives.
Moreover, there was no history of abdominal trauma in the past. The patient had a history of admissions to different hospitals for the recurrent pain attacks. However, apart from this illness, he had never been to hospitals for any other medical or surgical condition. He was on analgesics, insulin therapy, and pancreatic enzyme supplementation and had never been allergic to the exposed medications.

prompt:

Doctor: Hi, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm okay, doctor.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have a subcutaneous mass in my left superolateral orbital region. It's been present since I was 4 years old, and there have been no episodes of local infections.
Doctor: I see. And have you had any treatment for this mass before?
Patient: Yes, I had a partial resection of this mass 2 years ago at another department. Only the subcutaneous component of the cyst was ligated and resected. The pathological diagnosis was a dermoid cyst.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And what happened after the surgery?
Patient: Well, I developed a recurrent mass in the same region after 2 years.
Doctor: I see. Due to your active asthma and the history of adverse events that occurred after contrast MR imaging, contrast imaging studies were not performed. Can you tell me more about your asthma?
Patient: Yes, I have active asthma, and I had some adverse events after contrast MR imaging before.
Doctor: Okay. CT and MR imaging showed a subcutaneous mass with possible continuity to the Sylvian cistern by a tract in the sphenoid ridge and lesser wing of the sphenoid bone. As 2 years have passed since the initial surgery, we speculated the lesion had already penetrated the subarachnoid space through the dura based on the preoperative imaging. Do you have any headache or showed any signs of neurological deficits?
Patient: No, I don't have any headache or showed any signs of neurological deficits.
Doctor: Okay. While you had no headache or showed any signs of neurological deficits, we decided to reset the mass and the tract to prevent further recurrence. So, you underwent frontotemporal craniotomy. Can you tell me more about the surgery?
Patient: Yes, I underwent frontotemporal craniotomy. When musculocutaneous flap was retracted, the cyst duct was inadvertently damaged, resulting in spill out of greasy and whitish yellow cyst content.

The tumor was relatively large and fanning toward the skin, suggesting that dissection of the tumor through the temporal muscle and fascia could lead to damage to the frontal branch of the facial nerve. We thus cut the cyst duct and followed the duct toward the bone and to the dura. The duct looked ending in a blind pouch at the surface of the dura near the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone. As the lumen was exposed, yellowish debris and hair were appreciated. Intradural space was then carefully inspected and showed no evidence of lesion continuity. Finally, the remaining extracranial mass was totally resected with careful inspection of the facial nerve using a nerve stimulator.
Patient: Hmm, okay.

Patient: Okay, doctor.
Doctor: If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to call us.
Patient: Okay, thank you.

Patient: I was admitted to your institution for the evaluation of further therapeutic options for my metastatic malignant melanoma.

Doctor: Okay. And what treatments have you received so far?

In December 2010, I had another subcutaneous metastasis above the left base of the mandible, which was surgically resected. The analysis showed clear resection margins.
Doctor: Hmm, and what about adjuvant immunotherapy?
Patient: I started taking 3 million units of interferon-α thrice weekly in January 2011, but it was terminated in May 2011 due to increasing serum concentrations of the tumor marker S100, which indicated disease progression under therapy.

Patient: Another MRI scan performed in December 2011 showed regression of the left frontal brain metastasis and constant size of the right caudate nucleus lesion.
Doctor: Alright. And you're currently taking systemic therapy with temozolomide, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Alright, I'll need to review your case further and consult with my colleagues. We'll come up with a plan for your treatment and follow-up requirements.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
